Kim is the third and youngest son of [[Kim Jong-il]] (1941–2011) and his consort [[Ko Yong-hui]].Moore, Malcolm. [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/5428300/Kim-Jong-un-a-profile-of-North-Koreas-next-leader.html Kim Jong-un: a profile of North Korea's next leader]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''. 2 June 2009 Little is known for certain about Kim Jong-un. Before taking power, Kim had barely been seen in public, and many of the activities of both Kim and his government remain shrouded in secrecy.{{cite news|last1=News|first1=World|title=Who is North Korea's secretive Kim Jong Un? Here is what we know|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/04/05/17601453-who-is-north-koreas-secretive-kim-jong-un-here-is-what-we-know?lite|accessdate=28 May 2016|work=NBC News|date=5 April 2013}} Even details such as what year he was born, and whether he did indeed attend a Western school under a pseudonym, are difficult to confirm with certainty. Kim was officially declared the supreme leader following the [[Death and state funeral of Kim Jong-il|state funeral of his father]] on 28 December 2011. Kim holds the titles of [[Chairman of the Workers' Party of Korea]], Chairman of the [[Central Military Commission (DPRK)|Central Military Commission]], [[Chairman of the National Defence Commission]], [[Supreme Commander of the Korean People's Army]],{{cite news |title=N.Korea declares Kim Jong-Un commander of military |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jJYCeXinUm40ybUlJzb4_aOAiSAQ?docId=CNG.abd2d9a288a1831892829dfc484f077e.6a1 |accessdate=30 December 2011 |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=30 December 2011 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 February 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140224223520/www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jJYCeXinUm40ybUlJzb4_aOAiSAQ?docId=CNG.abd2d9a288a1831892829dfc484f077e.6a1}} and presidium member of the [[Politburo of the Workers' Party of Korea|Politburo]] of the [[Workers' Party of Korea]].[http://web.archive.org/web/20120114235905/http://ca.news.yahoo.com/kim-son-declared-supreme-leader-nkoreas-people-party-074210556.html North Korea tells rival SKorea and other nations not to expect any change, despite new leader]. The Associated Press (via Yahoo! News). 29 December 2011. Retrieved 1 January 2012. Kim was promoted to the rank of [[Marshal]] of North Korea in the [[Korean People's Army]] on 18 July 2012, consolidating his position as the Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces{{cite news|title=North Korea's Kim Jong-un named 'marshal'|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-18881524|accessdate=18 July 2012|publisher=BBC News|date=18 July 2012}} and is often referred to as Marshal Kim Jong-un or "the Marshal" by state media.{{cite news |title=North Korean leader orders to turn armed forces into elite revolutionary army |url=http://tass.ru/en/world/764640 |accessdate=28 December 2014 |agency=Information Telegraph Agency of Russia |date=2 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704075153/tass.ru/en/world/764640|archive-date=2015-07-04|dead-url=no}}{{cite news |title=Kim Jong-un’s latest no-show fuels further health rumours |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/oct/10/kim-jong-un-north-korea-health-rumours|accessdate=28 December 2014|work=The Guardian|issn=0261-3077|location=London, UK|date=10 October 2014}} Kim obtained two degrees, one in physics at [[Kim Il-sung University]], and another as an Army officer at the [[Kim Il-sung Military University]].[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2011/12/kim-jong-un-first-appearance.html Kim Jong Un makes first appearance since father's death]. ''Los Angeles Times'' (20 December 2011); retrieved 1 January 2012.{{cite web|last=Powell|first=Bill|date=22 December 2011|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2102985,00.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702154036/content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2102985,00.html|dead-url=no|archivedate=2 July 2015|title=The Generals Who Will Really Rule North Korea|work=Time|location=New York|issn=0040-781X}} On 9 March 2014, Kim Jong-un was elected unopposed to the [[Supreme People's Assembly]]. At {{age|1984|1|8}} years of age, Kim is the first North Korean leader born after the country's founding. Kim was named the World's 46th Most Powerful Person by the [[Forbes list of The World's Most Powerful People|''Forbes'' list of The World's Most Powerful People]] in 2013.{{cite web |first=Caroline |last=Howard |title=The World’s Most Powerful People 2013: No. 46: Kim Jong Un |url=http://www.forbes.com/pictures/lmh45kjle/no-46-kim-jong-un/ |work=Forbes |archive-url=http://webcitation.org/query?date=2015-12-26&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.forbes.com%2Fpictures%2Flmh45kjle%2Fno-46-kim-jong-un%2F |dead-url=no |archive-date=26 December 2015 |date=30 October 2013}} ==Early life and education== [[File:Schule Liebefeld-Steinhölzli, Köniz.jpg|thumb|left|The Liebefeld-Steinhölzli public school in [[Köniz]], [[Switzerland]], which Kim Jong-un is reported to have attended.]] Scarce information on Kim Jong-un's early life comes from [[North Korean defectors]] and people who have claimed to witness him abroad, such as during his school attendance in Switzerland. Some of the information has been conflicting and contradictory, perhaps conflating him with his brother, [[Kim Jong-chul]], who also attended school in Switzerland around the same time. Nevertheless, there has been some consensus on information about his early life. North Korean authorities have stated that his birthdate is 8 January 1982, but South Korean intelligence officials believe the actual date is a year later. [[Dennis Rodman]] said that the birthdate is 8 January 1983 after meeting Kim in September 2013.{{cite news|title=Rodman Gives Details on Trip to North Korea|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=9 September 2013|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/10/world/asia/rodman-gives-details-on-trip-to-north-korea.html|accessdate=10 September 2013}} Kim Jong-Un was the second of three children [[Ko Yong-hui]] bore to Kim Jong-il; his elder brother Kim Jong-chul was born in 1981, while his younger sister, [[Kim Yo-jong]], is believed to have been born in 1987.{{cite news |title=Kim Jong-un’s sister is having a ball |url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2957573 |archive-date=16 October 2015 |work=Korea JoongAng Daily |date=8 August 2012 |last1=Lee |first1=Young-jong |last2=Kim |first2=Hee-jin |dead-url=no |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016211015/koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2957573}}{{cite web |title=Kim Yo Jong |url=https://nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com/kji-2/kim-yo-jong/ |publisher=North Korea Leadership Watch |accessdate=15 October 2014 |date=11 July 2012}} According to reports first published in Japanese newspapers, he went to school in [[Switzerland]] near [[Bern]]. First reports claimed he attended the private English-language International School in [[Gümligen]] under the name "Chol-pak" or "Pak-chol" from 1993-98.{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/01/AR2009060103750.html|work=The Washington Post|author=Blaine Harden|title=Son Named Heir to North Korea's Kim Studied in Switzerland, Reportedly Loves NBA|date=3 June 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/7810203/Rare-photos-of-Kim-Jong-ils-youngest-son-Kim-Jong-un-released.html|location=London, UK|work=The Daily Telegraph|author=Peter Sun|first1=Allan|last1=Hall|title=Profile|date=25 November 2010}} He was described as shy, a good student who got along well with his classmates and was a basketball fan.{{cite news|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/02/kim-jong-il-names-son-successor|title=North Korean leader Kim Jong‑il ‘names youngest son as successor'|agency=Associated Press |work=The 2015|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016211014/www.theguardian.com/world/2009/jun/02/kim-jong-il-names-son-successor}} He was [[Chaperone (social)|chaperoned]] by an older student, who was thought to be his bodyguard.{{cite news|url=http://www.welt.de/welt_print/article3985896/Kim-Jong-un-und-sein-Unterricht-bei-den-Schweizern.html|title=Kim Jong-un und sein Unterricht bei den Schweizern|work=Die Welt|issn=0173-8437|location=Berlin|first=Elisalex|last=Henckel|date=24 June 2009|language=German|archivedate=27 July 2015|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150727053343/www.welt.de/welt_print/article3985896/Kim-Jong-un-und-sein-Unterricht-bei-den-Schweizern.html}} Later, it was reported that Kim Jong-un attended the Liebefeld Steinhölzli school in [[Köniz]] near Bern under the name "Pak-un" or "Un-pak" from 1998 until 2000 as the son of an employee of the Embassy of North Korea. Authorities of Köniz confirmed that a student from North Korea, registered as the son of a member of the Embassy, attended the school from August 1998 until the autumn of 2000, but were unable to give details about his identity. Pak-un first attended a special class for foreign-language children and later attended the regular classes of the 6th, 7th, 8th, and part of the final 9th year, leaving the school abruptly in the autumn of 2000. He was described as a well-integrated and ambitious student who liked to play basketball.{{cite web|url=http://www.nzz.ch/nachrichten/panorama/weitere_nordkoreanische_spuren_in_bern_1.2748091.html|title=Weitere nordkoreanische Spuren in Bern|work=Neue Zürcher Zeitung|date=16 June 2009|language=German|accessdate=19 December 2011}} However, his grades and attendance rating are reported to have been poor.{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/education/latest-news/poor-school-marks-of-north-koreas-kim-jongun-exposed-3068333.html|work=Irish Independent|issn=0791-685X|title=Poor school marks of North Korea's Kim Jong-un exposed|date=2 April 2012 |archive-url=http://webcitation.org/query?date=2015-12-26&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.independent.ie%2Flife%2Ffamily%2Flearning%2Fpoor-school-marks-of-north-koreas-kim-jongun-exposed-26838819.html|archive-date=26 December 2015|dead-url=no}}{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9180501/Kim-Jong-uns-poor-marks-exposed.html|location=London, UK|work=The Daily Telegraph|title=Kim Jong-un's poor marks exposed|date=2 April 2012}} The ambassador of North Korea in Switzerland, Ri Tcheul, had a close relationship with him and acted as a mentor.{{cite web |url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/international/2010/09/05/01003-20100905ARTFIG00221-kim-jong-un-une-education-suisse-entouree-de-mysteres.php |title=Kim Jong-un : une éducation suisse entourée de mystères |work=Le Figaro |language=French |accessdate=19 December 2011}} One of Pak-un's classmates told reporters that he had told him that he was the son of the leader of North Korea.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/09/28/north.korea.heir.friend/ |publisher=CNN |title=North Korea: Nuclear Tension |date=29 September 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150609120331/www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/09/28/north.korea.heir.friend|archivedate=9 June 2015|dead-url=no|first=Atika |last=Shubert}}{{cite web|title=Mein Freund, der zukünftige Diktator Nordkoreas|author=Bernhard Odenahl|date=29 September 2009|work=Tages-Anzeiger|language=German|url=http://www.tagesanzeiger.ch/ausland/asien-und-ozeanien/Mein-Freund-der-zukuenftige-Diktator-Nordkoreas-/story/20634972|accessdate=29 September 2010}} According to some reports, Jong-un was described by classmates as a shy child who was awkward with girls and indifferent to political issues but who distinguished himself in sports, and had a fascination with the American [[National Basketball Association]] and [[Michael Jordan]]. One friend claimed that he had been shown pictures of Pak-un with [[Kobe Bryant]] and [[Toni Kukoč]].{{cite web|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2009/07/17/2009071700693.html|title=Classmates Recall Kim Jong-un's Basketball Obsession|work=The Chosun Ilbo|date=17 July 2009|accessdate=19 December 2011}} In April 2012, new documents came to light indicating that Kim Jong-un had lived in Switzerland since 1991 or 1992, earlier than previously thought.{{cite news|url=http://www.lematin.ch/suisse/kim-jongun-reste-neuf-ans-suisse/story/20273993|title=Kim Jong-un est resté neuf ans en Suisse|author=Titus Plattner|accessdate=24 April 2012|date=21 April 2012|work=Le Matin|language=French}} The Laboratory of Anatomic Anthropology at the [[University of Lyon]], France, after comparing the picture of the boy Pak-un taken at the Liebefeld Steinhölzli school in 1999 with a picture of Kim Jong-un from 2012 came to the conclusion that the two faces show a conformity of 95%. The head of the institute, Raoul Perrot, a forensic anthropologist, considers it most likely that the two pictures show the same person.{{cite web|author1=Titus Plattner |author2=Daniel Glaus |author3=Julian Schmidli |url=http://www.sonntagszeitung.ch/fokus/artikel-detailseite/?newsid=212533 |title=Der Diktator aus Liebefeld |work=[[SonntagsZeitung]] |date=1 April 2012 |page=17 |language=German |accessdate=2 April 2012 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/66cIlKe2M |archivedate=2 April 2012 }}«Der Schüler Un Pak ist identisch mit Kim Jong-un.» It is believed that the student at the Gümligen International School was not Kim Jong-un but his elder brother Kim Jong-chol. It is not known whether the student known as Pak-un in Liebefeld Steinhölzli lived in Switzerland prior to 1998.{{cite journal|title=Der Diktator spricht Deutsch|first1=Titus|last1=Plattner|first2=Julie|last2=Zaugg |date=8 May 2009|work=Cicero|url=http://www.cicero.de/weltbühne/der-diktator-spricht-deutsch/39681|language=de|archive-date=30 September 2015|issn=1613-4826|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150930081816/www.cicero.de/weltbühne/der-diktator-spricht-deutsch/39681}} All the children of Kim Jong-il are said to have lived in Switzerland, as well as the mother of the two youngest sons, who lived in Geneva for some time. Most analysts agree that Kim Jong-un attended [[Kim Il-sung University]], a leading officer-training school in Pyongyang, from 2002 to 2007.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/15/world/asia/15kim.html|title=North Korea's Heir Apparent Remains a Mystery|author=Choe Sang-Hun and Martin Fackler|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=14 June 2009|accessdate=2 April 2012}} For many years, only one confirmed photograph of him was known outside North Korea, apparently taken in the mid-1990s, when he was eleven.{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11389824|title=Tales of starvation and death in North Korea|publisher=BBC|date=22 September 2010|accessdate=28 September 2010}} Occasional other supposed images of him surfaced but were often disputed.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/asia-pacific/8078562.stm Profile: Kim Jong-un], BBC News, 2 June 2009{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/25/world/asia/25succession.html|work=The New York Times|title=North Korea Appears to Tap Leader's Son as Enigmatic Heir|author=Martin Fackler|date=24 April 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2010/04/21/2010042100633.html|title=Confusion Over Photo of N. Korean Leader‑to‑Be|work=The Chosun Ilbo|accessdate=28 September 2010}} It was only in June 2010, shortly before he was given official posts and publicly introduced to the North Korean people, that more pictures were released of Kim, taken when he was attending school in Switzerland.{{Cite news|title=The son also rises|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2921577|newspaper=JoongAng Daily|date=9 June 2010}}{{Cite news|author=Peter Foster|title=Rare photos of Kim Jong-il's youngest son, Kim Jong-un, released|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/7810203/Rare-photos-of-Kim-Jong-ils-youngest-son-Kim-Jong-un-released.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=8 June 2010|location=London, UK}} The first official image of him as an adult was a group photograph released on 30 September 2010, at the end of the party conference that effectively anointed him, in which he is seated in the front row, two places from his father. This was followed by newsreel footage of him attending the conference.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11441504 New images of North Korea's heir apparent Kim Jong-un], BBC News, 30 September 2010. In 2013, Kim Jong-un was awarded an honorary doctorate in Economics by [[HELP University]], a private [[Malaysia]]n university.{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2013/10/23/HELP-uni-kim-jong-un-phd|title=HELP University awards honorary doctorate to Kim Jong‑Un|work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]|date=23 October 2013|first=Dina|last=Murad}} ==Succession== ===Pre-2010 Party Conference speculation=== His eldest half-brother, [[Kim Jong-nam]], had been the favorite to succeed, but reportedly fell out of favor after 2001, when he was caught attempting to enter Japan on a [[fake passport]] to visit [[Tokyo Disneyland]].[http://www.rthk.org.hk/rthk/news/englishnews/news.htm?main&20090718&56&597742 Kim Jong-il's grandson seen at concert]. [[RTHK]], 18 July 2009. Kim Jong-il's former personal chef, [[Kenji Fujimoto]], revealed details regarding Kim Jong-un, with whom he had a good relationship,Lynn, Hyung Gu. (2007). ''Bipolar orders: the two Koreas since 1989.'' Zed Books. p. 122. ISBN 978-1-84277-743-5. stating that he was favored to be his father's successor. Fujimoto also claimed that Jong-un was favored by his father over his elder brother, Kim Jong-chul, reasoning that Jong-chul is too feminine in character, while Jong-un is "exactly like his father".Sang-hun, Choe; Fackler, Martin. [http://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/15/world/asia/15kim.html North Korea's Heir Apparent Remains a Mystery]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. 14 June 2009 Furthermore, Fujimoto stated that "If power is to be handed over then Jong-un is the best for it. He has superb physical gifts, is a big drinker and never admits defeat." Also, according to Fujimoto, Jong-un smokes [[Saint Laurent Paris|Yves Saint Laurent]] cigarettes, loves [[Johnnie Walker]] whisky and has a [[Mercedes-Benz 600]] Sedan.[http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2010/12/20/2010122001136.html ''The Chosun Ilbo'' "Kim Jong-un 'Loves Nukes, Computer Games and Johnny Walker"] (20 December 2010). Retrieved 23 April 2013. When Jong-un was 18, Fujimoto described an episode where Jong-un once questioned his lavish lifestyle and asked, "We are here, playing basketball, riding horses, riding Jet Skis, having fun together. But what of the lives of the average people?" On 15 January 2009 the [[South Korean]] news agency [[Yonhap]] reported that Kim Jong-il had appointed Kim Jong-un to be his successor.[http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/northkorea/2009/01/22/62/0401000000AEN20090121007400325F.HTML North Korea Newsletter No. 38]. Yonhap. 22 January 2009. On 8 March 2009, [[BBC News]] reported that Kim Jong-un was on the ballot for elections to the [[Supreme People's Assembly]], the [[rubber stamp (politics)|rubber stamp parliament]] of North Korea.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7930775.stm "N Korea holds parliamentary poll"]. [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 8 March 2009. Subsequent reports indicated that his name did not appear on the list of lawmakers,{{cite web |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601086&sid=aFAm9ndQmJpI&refer=latin_america |title=Kim Jong Il’s Son, Possible Successor, Isn’t Named as Lawmaker |publisher=Bloomberg |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629121818/www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aFAm9ndQmJpI&refer=latin_america |archive-date=29 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |author=Heejin Koo |date=9 March 2009}} but he was later elevated to a mid-level position in the National Defense Commission, which is a branch of the North Korean military.{{cite web |first=James |last=Rosen |date=1 May 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504024115/www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/05/01/north-korea-kim-begins-shifting-power-military/ |archive-date=2009-05-04 |title=In North Korea, Ailing Kim Begins Shifting Power to Military |publisher=Fox News |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/05/01/north-korea-ailing-kim-begins-shifting-power-military.html}} [[File:The statues of Kim Il Sung and Kim Jong Il on Mansu Hill in Pyongyang (april 2012).jpg|thumb|260px|North Koreans bowing to the statues of [[Kim Il-sung]] and [[Kim Jong-il]]]] From 2009, it was understood by foreign diplomatic services that Kim was to succeed his father Kim Jong-il as the head of the Korean Workers' Party and de facto leader of North Korea.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8078324.stm|title=N Korea names Kim's successor named|publisher=BBC|date=2 June 2009|accessdate=14 June 2009}} He has been named "Yŏngmyŏng-han Tongji" (영명한 동지), which loosely translates to "Brilliant Comrade".{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2009/06/13/north-korean-leader039s-son-039brilliant-comrade039.html|title=North Korean leader's son is 'Brilliant Comrade|publisher=[[The Jakarta Post]]|date=13 June 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303175033/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2009/06/13/north-korean-leader039s-son-039brilliant-comrade039.html|archivedate=3 March 2016}} His father had also asked embassy staff abroad to pledge loyalty to his son. There have also been reports that citizens in North Korea were encouraged to sing a newly composed "song of praise" to Kim Jong-un, in a similar fashion to that of [[Song of General Kim Jong-il|praise songs relating to Kim Jong-il]] and [[Song of General Kim Il-sung|Kim Il-sung]].{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2009/s2632675.htm|title=North Koreans sing praises of dynastic dictatorship|work=AM|date=22 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725031711/www.abc.net.au/am/content/2009/s2632675.htm|archivedate=25 July 2009|dead-url=no|first=Mark|last=Willacy|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|location=Sydney}} Later, in June, Kim was reported to have visited China secretly to "present himself" to the Chinese leadership, who later warned against North Korea conducting another nuclear test.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article6508436.ece Kim Jong Il's son 'made secret visit to China']. ''[[The Times]]''. 16 June 2009. The Chinese Foreign Ministry has strongly denied that this visit occurred.[http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2009/06/19/2009061900402.html China Dismisses Reports of Kim Jong-un Visit]. ''[[The Chosun Ilbo]]''. 19 June 2009Harden, Blaine. [http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/06/01/AR2009060103750.html North Korea's Kim Jong Il Chooses Youngest Son as Heir], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', 3 June 2009. North Korea was later reported to have backed the succession plan, after Kim Jong-il suspended a propaganda campaign to promote his youngest son.{{cite news |first=Chang-Won|last=Lim|date=6 September 2009|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gvACCP7QGFdDDvwHxcbIph2Yw4pw|title={{not a typo|N|Korea}} backs Kim’s succession plan: analysts|agency=Agence France-Presse|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219202429/www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gvACCP7QGFdDDvwHxcbIph2Yw4pw|archivedate=19 February 2014|dead-url=yes}} His birthday has since become a [[Public holidays in North Korea|national holiday]], celebrated on 8 January, according to a report by a South Korean website.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/8221155/North-Korea-declare-Kim-Jong-uns-birthday-a-public-holiday.html|title=North Korea declare Kim Jong-un's birthday a public holiday|date=23 December 2010|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=6 January 2012|location=London, UK}} He was expected to be named on 28 September 2010 as successor to his father as leader of North Korea.[http://koreajoongangdaily.joinsmsn.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2905585 Sources: Kim chooses third son as heir], ''[[JoongAng Daily]]'', 2 June 2009.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11152682 Sources: Is North Korea's Kim poised to name his successor?], [[BBC News]], 1 September 2010.{{cite news|author=John Sudworth |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11378145|title=North Korea sets date for rare leadership conference|publisher=BBC|date=21 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}} Former U.S. president [[Jimmy Carter]] visited China in early September 2010, and discussed the issue of the North Korean leadership succession with Chinese Premier [[Wen Jiabao]]. According to Carter, Kim Jong-il had said to Wen that Kim Jong-un's prospective promotion to paramount leader of North Korea was "a false rumor from the West".{{cite news |url=http://www.cartercenter.org/news/trip_reports/china-090410.html|title=Trip Report by Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter to China, Sept. 4–10, 2010|publisher=The Carter Center|accessdate=28 September 2010}} It is believed by some that Kim Jong-un was involved in the [[ROKS Cheonan sinking|''Cheonan'' sinking]]{{cite web|title=North Korean Propagandists Say Kim Jong‑il's Son Planned South Korea Attacks|work=International Business Times|date=24 December 2011|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/north-korean-propagandists-say-kim-jong-ils-son-planned-south-korea-attacks-387228|archivedate=26 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151226192629/www.ibtimes.com/north-korean-propagandists-say-kim-jong-ils-son-planned-south-korea-attacks-387228|dead-url=no|first=Amrutha|last=Gayathri}} and the [[bombardment of Yeonpyeong]]{{cite web|title=Kim Jong-un 'Masterminded Attacks on S. Korea'|work=The Chosun Ilbo|date=3 August 2011|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2011/08/03/2011080300499.html|accessdate=13 January 2012}} to strengthen his military credentials and facilitate a successful transition of power from his father.{{cite web|title=Korean Peninsula: After Cheonan Warship Sinking and Yeonpyeong Incidents|last=Chun|first=Kwang Ho|date=2011|publisher=Jeju Peace Institute|url=http://jpi.or.kr/skyboard/download.sky?code=jpiworld&fid=3286&gid=5322|archive-date=26 December 2015|format=PDF|archive-url=http://webcitation.org/query?date=2015-12-26&url=http%3A%2F%2Fjpi.or.kr%2Fskyboard%2Fdownload.sky%3Fcode%3Djpiworld%26fid%3D3286%26gid%3D5322}} ===Vice Chairman of the Central Military Commission=== Kim Jong-un was made a ''[[daejang]]'', the equivalent of a four-star [[General (United States)|general]] in the United States,{{cite news |title=Is North Korea following the Chinese model? |publisher=BBC News |date=29 September 2010 |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11432894 |accessdate=30 September 2010}} on 27 September 2010, a day ahead of a rare [[Workers' Party of Korea]] conference in Pyongyang, the first time North Korean media had mentioned him by name and despite his having no previous military experience.{{cite news |title=North Korea sets date for rare leadershipconference|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11378145|accessdate=27 September 2010|publisher=BBC News|date=21 September 2010}}{{cite news|title=North Korean leader Kim Jong-il's son 'made a general'|publisher=BBC News|date=28 September 2010|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11417016|accessdate=28 September 2010}}{{cite news|title=North Korea's Kim paves way for family succession|publisher=BBC News|date=28 September 2010|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11426284|accessdate=28 September 2010}} Despite the promotion, no further details, including verifiable portraits of Kim, were released.{{cite web|author=Matt Negrin|url=http://www.politico.com/politico44/perm/0910/little_kim_rises_47f34787-5587-48fd-b2a4-c11fa6a56599.html|title=N. Korean leader promotes his son|publisher=Politico.com|date=28 September 2010|accessdate=28 September 2010}} On 28 September 2010, he was named vice chairman of the [[Central Military Commission (DPRK)|Central Military Commission]] and appointed to the [[Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea|Central Committee of the Workers' Party]], in an apparent nod to become the successor to Kim Jong-il.{{Cite journal|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11431415|publisher=BBC News|title=North Korea leader's son given key party posts|date=28 September 2010}} On 10 October 2010, alongside his father, Kim Jong-un attended the ruling Workers' Party's 65th anniversary celebration. This was seen as fully confirming his position as the next leader of the Workers' Party. Unprecedented international press access was granted to the event, further indicating the importance of Kim Jong-un's presence.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/world/asia/10korea.html|work=The New York Times|title=Kim Jong-il's Heir Attends Parade|date=9 October 2010|author=Mark McDonald}} In January 2011, the regime reportedly began purging around 200 protégés of both Jong-un's uncle-in-law [[Jang Sung-taek]] and [[O Kuk-ryol]], the vice chairman of the [[National Defence Commission of North Korea]], by either detention or execution to further prevent either man from rivaling Jong-un.{{cite news|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2011/01/10/2011011000554.html|title=N.Korea 'Purging Proteges of the Old Guard'|work=[[The Chosun Ilbo]]|date=10 January 2011|accessdate=19 December 2011}} In the following months, Kim Jong-un was given more and more prominence as he accompanied Kim Jong-il during several "[[on the spot guidance|guidance tours]]" and received gifts from foreign delegations and personages, an honor traditionally awarded only to the living supreme leader.{{cn|date=July 2016}} ==Ruler of North Korea== On 17 December 2011, Kim Jong-il died. Despite the elder Kim's plans, it was not immediately clear after his death whether Jong-un would in fact take full power, and what his exact role in a new government would be.{{cite news|title=Kim Jong-il, North Korean leader, dies|first=Tania|last=Branigan|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/19/kim-jong-il-north-korean-leader-dies|work=The Guardian|date=19 December 2011|archive-date=14 August 2015|location=London, UK|issn=0261-3077|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150814114449/www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/19/kim-jong-il-north-korean-leader-dies |dead-url=no}} Some analysts had predicted that when Kim Jong-il died, [[Jang Sung-taek]] would act as [[regent]], as Jong-un was too inexperienced to immediately lead the country.{{cite news|title=Kim Jong‑il's heir Kim Jong‑un made general|first1=Rick|last1=Wallace|first2=Michael|last2=Sainsbury|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/kim-jong-ils-heir-kim-jong-un-made-general/story-e6frg6so-1225931178505 |newspaper=The Australian|issn=1038-8761|date=29 September 2010 |archive-date=25 December 2013 |dead-url=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225061032/www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/kim-jong-ils-heir-kim-jong-un-made-general/story-e6frg6so-1225931178505}} On 25 December 2011, North Korean television showed Jang Sung-taek in the uniform of a general in a sign of his growing sway after the death of Kim Jong-il. A Seoul official familiar with North Korea affairs said it was the first time Jang has been shown on state television in a military uniform. His appearance suggested that Jang had secured a key role in the North's powerful military, which pledged its allegiance to Kim Jong-un.{{cite web |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/us-korea-north-power-idUSTRE7BO02I20111225|title=North Korean power‑behind‑throne emerges as neighbors meet|publisher=Reuters|date=25 December 2011 |archive-date=7 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160107225817/www.reuters.com/article/us-korea-north-power-idUSTRE7BO02I20111225|dead-url=no|first1=Sung-won|last1=Shim|first2=Kiyoshi|last2=Takenaka|first3=Chris|last3=Buckley|editor-first=Yoko|editor-last=Nishikawa}} [[North Korea's cult of personality]] around Kim Jong-un was stepped up following his father's death. He was hailed as the "great successor to the revolutionary cause of [[Juche]]", "outstanding leader of the party, army and people"{{cite web|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2011/201112/news19/20111219-04ee.html|title=Notice to All Party Members, Servicepersons and People|publisher=Korean Central News Agency|date=19 December 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150311064222/www.kcna.co.jp/item/2011/201112/news19/20111219-04ee.html|archive-date=11 March 2015}} and "respected comrade who is identical to Supreme Commander Kim Jong-il",{{cite web|url=http://www.kcna.co.jp/item/2011/201112/news19/20111219-12ee.html|title=We Are under Respected Kim Jong Un|publisher=Korean Central News Agency|date=19 December 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141012023229/www.kcna.co.jp/item/2011/201112/news19/20111219-12ee.html|archivedate=12 October 2014}} and was made chairman of the Kim Jong-il funeral committee. The [[Korean Central News Agency]] described Kim Jong-un as "a great person born of heaven", a propaganda term only his father and grandfather had enjoyed,Associated Press (19 December 2011). [http://web.archive.org/web/20120113085114/http://www.chron.com/news/article/NKorea-grieves-Kim-Jong-Il-state-media-hails-son-2411026.php NKorea grieves Kim Jong Il, state media hails son], ''Houston Chronicle''; retrieved 1 January 2012. while the ruling Workers' Party said in an editorial: "We vow with bleeding tears to call Kim Jong-un our supreme commander, our leader."{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-12-24/north-korea-s-media-begins-referring-to-kim-jong-un-as-supreme-commander- |title=N. Korea Media Begins Calling Kim Jong Un Supreme Commander|publisher=Bloomberg|date=24 December 2011|last=Lee |first=Jiyeun}} He was publicly declared [[Supreme Commander of the Korean People's Army]] on 24 December 2011{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16325390|title=North Korea: Kim Jong-un hailed 'supreme commander'|date=24 December 2011|accessdate=24 December 2011|publisher=BBC News}} and formally appointed to the position on 30 December when the Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Workers' Party "courteously proclaimed that the dear respected Kim Jong Un, vice-chairman of the Central Military Commission of the {{abbr|WPK|Workers' Party of Korea}}, assumed the supreme commandership of the Korean People's Army". [[File:Revolutionary Martyrs Cemetery 32.JPG|thumb|[[Revolutionary Martyrs' Cemetery]] in Pyongyang, 2012]] On 26 December 2011, the leading North Korean newspaper ''[[Rodong Sinmun]]'' announced that Kim Jong-un had been acting as chairman of the Central Military Commission,[http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/topics/2011/12/26/81/4603000000AEN20111226003700315F.HTML N. Korean newspaper refers to successor son as head of key party organ] Yonhap News Agency, 26 December 2011. and supreme leader of the country, following his father's demise.{{cite news |author=Scott McDonald |url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/story/2011-12-30/north-korea-leadership/52280412/1 |title=North Korea vows no softening toward South |date=30 December 2011 |work=USA Today}} On 9 January 2012, a large rally was held by [[Korean People's Army]] in front of [[Kumsusan Memorial Palace]] to honor Kim Jong-un and demonstrate loyalty.{{cite web|title=Military Rallies in Keumsusan Square|author=So Yeol Kim|accessdate=10 January 2012|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01700&num=8664}} ===Assuming official titles=== On 27 March 2012, Kim was elected to the Fourth Conference of the Workers' Party of Korea. On 11 April, that conference elected him as leader of the party under the newly created title of First Secretary. This position replaced the post of General Secretary, which was awarded "eternally" to Kim Jong-il. At the conference, Kim Jong-un also took his father's post as Chairman of the Central Military Commission, as well as his father's old seat on the Politburo Presidium.{{cite web |title=Kim Takes More Top Posts |author=Chris Green |accessdate=12 April 2012 |url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01700&num=9100}} In a speech made prior to the Conference, Kim Jong-un declared that "Imbuing the whole society with Kimilsungism-Kimjongilism is the highest programme of our Party". On 13 April 2012, the 5th Session of the 12th Supreme People's Assembly appointed Kim Jong-un [[Chairman of the National Defence Commission]]. On 15 April 2012, during a military parade to commemorate Kim Il-sung's centenary, Kim Jong-un made his first public speech.{{cite news |publisher=BBC |accessdate=14 April 2012 |date=14 April 2012 |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-17718011 |title=N Korea's Kim Jong-un speaks publicly for first time}} That speech became the basis of "[[Onwards Toward the Final Victory]]", a repeatedly aired propaganda hymn dedicated to him.{{cite news|first=Tania|last=Branigan|title=North Korea's Kim Jong-un gets new official theme song|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/06/north-korea-kim-jong-un-song|archive-date=2 August 2015|work=The Guardian|date=6 July 2012|issn=0261-3077|location=London, UK|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150802102716/www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/06/north-korea-kim-jong-un-song|dead-url=no}} In July 2012, Kim Jong-un was promoted to [[Wonsu (North Korea)|wonsu]] (roughly translated to [[marshal]]), the highest active rank in the military. The decision was jointly issued on by the [[Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea|Central Committee]] and the [[Central Military Commission (North Korea)|Central Military Commission]] of the [[Workers' Party of Korea]], the [[National Defence Commission of North Korea|National Defence Commission]], and the [[Presidium]] of the [[Supreme People's Assembly]], the [[Korean Central News Agency]] subsequently announced. The only higher rank is [[Dae Wonsu]] (roughly translated as [[Grand Marshal]] or [[Generalissimo]]) which was held by Kim's grandfather, Kim Il-sung, and which was awarded posthumously to his father, Kim Jong-il, in February 2012.{{cite news|last=Green|first=Chris|title=Kim Jong Eun Promoted to Marshal|url=http://www.dailynk.com/english/read.php?cataId=nk01700&num=9533|accessdate=18 July 2012|work=Daily NK|date=18 July 2012}} The promotion confirmed Kim's role as top leader of the North Korean military and came days after the replacement of Chief of General Staff [[Ri Yong-ho]] by [[Hyon Yong-chol]]. During a 2012 performance marking the anniversary of the [[Korean Armistice Agreement]], security around Kim reportedly increased dramatically because Kim "is extremely nervous about the possibility of an emergency developing inside North Korea" caused by "mounting opposition to his efforts to rein in the military".{{cite web |title=Kim Jong-un Beefs Up Security Amid Fear of Unrest |url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2012/12/06/2012120601143.html |work=Chosun Ilbo |accessdate=6 December 2012 |date=6 December 2012 }} In November 2012, satellite photos revealed a half-kilometer-long ({{convert|0.5|km|ft|disp=out}}) propaganda message carved into a hillside in [[Ryanggang Province]], reading, "Long Live General Kim Jong-un, the Shining Sun!" The message, located next to an artificial lake built in 2007 to serve a hydroelectric station, is made of Korean syllable blocks measuring {{convert|15|by|20|m}}, and is located approximately {{convert|9|km}} south of [[Hyesan]] near the [[China–North Korea border|border with China]].{{cite news|title=Half-kilometre long Kim Jong-un propaganda message visible from space|work=National Post|issn=1486-8008|archive-date=21 December 2015|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/half-kilometre-long-kim-jong-un-propaganda-message-visible-from-space|dead-url=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151221115623/news.nationalpost.com/news/half-kilometre-long-kim-jong-un-propaganda-message-visible-from-space|date=23 November 2012}} Kim Jong-il's personal chef [[Kenji Fujimoto]] stated, "Stores in Pyongyang were brimming with products and people in the streets looked cheerful. North Korea has changed a lot since Kim Jong-un assumed power. All of this is because of leader Kim Jong-un."{{cite web|first=Justin|last=McCurry|date=10 August 2012|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/aug/10/kim-jong-il-japan-chef|title=Kim Jong‑il's personal Japanese chef returns to land he fled|work=The Guardian|archivedate=2 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702173449/www.theguardian.com/world/2012/aug/10/kim-jong-il-japan-chef|dead-url=no|location=London, UK|issn=0261-3077}} Officially, Kim Jong-un is part of a [[triumvirate]] heading the executive branch of the North Korean government along with Premier [[Pak Pong-ju]] and parliament chairman [[Kim Yong-nam]] (no relation). Each nominally holds powers equivalent to a third of a president's powers in most other presidential systems. Kim Jong-un commands the armed forces, Pak Pong-ju heads the government, and Kim Yong-nam handles foreign relations. Nevertheless, it is generally understood that Kim Jong-un, like his father and grandfather before him, exercises absolute control over the government and the country. Indeed, a constitutional amendment enacted by his father explicitly named the NDC (first) chairman as "the supreme leader of the Democratic People's Republic of North Korea".{{Cite web | title = DPRK has quietly amended its Constitution | last = Petrov | first = Leonid | work = Leonid Petrov's KOREA VISION | date = 12 October 2009 | accessdate = 12 September 2015 | url = https://leonidpetrov.wordpress.com/2009/10/12/dprk-has-quietly-amended-its-constitution/}}{{cite book|others=Amended and supplemented on April 1, Juche 102 (2013), at the Seventh Session of the Twelfth Supreme People's Assembly|title=Socialist Constitution of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea|url=http://www.naenara.com.kp/en/book/download.php?4+4047|year=2014|format=PDF|publisher=Foreign Languages Publishing House|location=Pyongyang|isbn=978-9946-0-1099-1|page=22|chapter=Article 100}} On 30 November 2012, Kim met with [[Li Jianguo]], who "briefed Kim on the [[18th National Congress of the Communist Party of China|18th National Congress]] of the [[Communist Party of China]]", according to the state's official news agency, the [[Korean Central News Agency]].{{cite web |title=Kim Jong-un Gets Letter from China's New Leader|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2012/12/03/2012120301309.html|publisher=Chosun.com|accessdate=6 December 2012|date=3 December 2012}} A letter from [[Xi Jinping]] was hand-delivered during the discussion. In 2013, Kim re-established his grandfather's style when he made his first New Year's address, a break from the approach of his father. Kim Jong-il never made televised addresses during his 17 years in power.[http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/01/world/asia/north-korea-kim-speech/index.html In first New Year speech, North Korea's Kim Jong Un calls for economic revamp], CNN.com, 2 January 2013; retrieved 23 April 2013. In lieu of delivering a speech, Kim Jong-il contributed to and approved a New Year's Day editorial, jointly published by ''Rodong Sinmun'' (the daily newspaper of the Korean Workers' Party), ''[[Joson Inmingun]]'' (the newspaper of the Korean People's Army), and ''[[Chongnyon Jonwi]]'' (the newspaper of the [[Kim Il-sung Socialist Youth League]]).[http://nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com/ "KJU Delivers New Year's Day Address"]. Nkleadershipwatch.wordpress.com; retrieved 23 April 2013. At the extraordinary meeting with his top defense and security officials on 26 January 2013, Kim issued orders on preparations for a new nuclear test and introduced [[martial law]] in North Korea effective from 29 January.{{cite web|title=North Korea 'under martial law'|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9838626/North-Korea-under-martial-law.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=31 January 2013|date=31 January 2013}}{{cite news|script-title=ru:В КНДР в преддверии ядерных испытаний введено военное положение|url=http://ria.ru/world/20130131/920676089.html|agency=[[RIA Novosti]]|language=Russian|accessdate=31 January 2013|date=31 January 2013}} In May 2014, following the collapse of an apartment building in Pyongyang, Kim Jong-un was said to be very upset at the loss of life that resulted. A statement issued by the country's official news agency the [[Korean Central News Agency]] used the rare expression "profound consolation and apology". An unnamed government official was quoted by the [[BBC]] as saying Kim Jong-un had "sat up all night, feeling painful".{{Cite web | title = North Korea offers rare apology after apartment building collapses | last = Chasmar |first = Jessica | work = The Washingtion Times | date = 18 May 2014 | accessdate = 2 January 2015 | url = http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/may/18/north-korea-offers-rare-apology-after-apartment-bu/}} While the height of the building and the number of casualties was not released, media reports described it is a 23-story building and indicated that more than a hundred people may have died in the collapse.{{Cite web | title = North Korea: Apology over Pyongyang building collapse | work = BBC News | date = 18 May 2014 | accessdate = 4 August 2016 | url = http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-27459186}} On 9 March 2014, Kim Jong-un was elected to the [[Supreme People's Assembly]]. He was unopposed, but voters had the choice of voting yes or no. There was a record turnout of voters, and according to government officials, all voted ''yes''.{{Cite web | title = North Korea's Kim Jong-un elected to assembly without single vote against | agency = Associated Press | work = The Guardian | date = 10 March 2014 | accessdate = 4 August 2016 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/mar/10/north-koreas-kim-jong-un-elected-assembly-vote-against}} The Supreme People's Assembly subsequently elected him first chairman of the [[National Defense Commission]].{{Cite web | title = Leader Tightens Hold on Power in North Korea | last = Sang-Hun | first = Choe | work = The New York Times | date = 9 April 2014 | accessdate = 4 August 2016 | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/10/world/asia/kim-further-consolidates-power-as-north-koreas-leader.html}} ===Economic policies=== In August 2012, Kim Jong-un announced economics reforms similar to China.Mike Firn (6 August 2012) [http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9455190/Kim-Jong-un-planning-China-like-reforms-in-North-Korea.html Kim Jong-un 'planning China-like reforms in North Korea']. ''The Daily Telegraph''. Retrieved 23 April 2013. Kim began to be mentioned by the North Korean state media as "supreme leader" (''chego ryongdoja'') at this time. A set of comprehensive economic measures, the "Socialist Corporate Responsible Management System", were introduced in 2013. The measures increase the autonomy of enterprises by granting them "certain rights to engage in business activities autonomously and elevate the will to labor through appropriately implementing the socialist distribution system". Another priority of economic policies that year was agriculture, where the ''pojon'' (vegetable garden) responsibility system was implemented. The system reportedly achieved a major increase in output in some collective farms.{{cite web |url=http://ifes.kyungnam.ac.kr/eng/FRM/FRM_0101V.aspx?code=FRM150224_0001 |title="Socialist Enterprise Management System" under Full Implementation |publisher=Institute for Far Eastern Studies |date=24 February 2015 |accessdate=28 April 2015}} North Korean media were describing the economy as a "flexible collectivist system" where enterprises were applying "active and evolutionary actions" to achieve economic development. These reports reflect Kim's general economic policy of reforming management, increasing the autonomy and incentives for economic actors. This set of reforms known as the "May 30th measures" reaffirms both socialist ownership and "objective economic laws in guidance and management" to improve living standards. Other objectives of the measures are to increase the availability of domestically manufactured goods on markets, introduction of defence innovations into the civilian sector and boost international trade.{{cite web |url=http://ifes.kyungnam.ac.kr/eng/FRM/FRM_0101V.aspx?code=FRM150115_0001 |title=Kim Jong Un Stresses the Principles of Market Economy through ‘May 30th Measures’ |publisher=Institute for Far Eastern Studies |date=15 January 2015 |accessdate=28 April 2015}} ===Nuclear threats=== {{See also|North Korea and weapons of mass destruction}} [[File:Unha-9 rocket model.jpg|thumb|left|Model of a [[Unha]]-9 rocket on display at a floral exhibition in Pyongyang, 30 August 2013]] On 7 March 2013, North Korea threatened the [[United States]] with a "pre-emptive nuclear attack",[http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/03/07/17220065-un-passes-sanctions-despite-north-korea-threat-of-pre-emptive-nuclear-attack UN passes sanctions despite North Korea threat of 'pre-emptive nuclear attack']. NBC News. 7 March 2013. and Kim Jong-un issued a detailed threat to "wipe out" [[Baengnyeong Island]], the scene of previous naval clashes.{{cite news |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gDrMpWuahcuRgQmj-dSSk_L87w2g?docId=CNG.ece624233e0176d14a79a8a1f72e2f75.161 |title=N. Korean leader threatens strike on South island |agency=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=11 March 2013 |accessdate=2 April 2013 |archivedate=2 April 2013 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6Fark00hx}} North Korea has revealed plans for conducting nuclear strikes on U.S. cities, including [[Los Angeles]], and [[Washington, D.C.]][http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/northkorea/9960933/North-Korea-plan-to-attack-US-mainland-revealed-in-photographs.html North Korea plan to attack US mainland revealed in photographs]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' (29 March 2013). The boastful claim was made during a visit by Kim to the Phyongchon Revolutionary Site, a museum dedicated to his grandfather Kim Il-sung.{{cite web |title=Kim Jong-Un claims North Korea has a hydrogen bomb |url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2015/12/10/kim-jong-un-claims-north-korea-has-hydrogen-bomb/?intcmp=hplnws |publisher=Fox News |accessdate=11 December 2015}} ===Other unsupported claims=== In June 2016, Kim announced via a spokesman that North Korean scientists had created a "wonder drug", composed of [[ginseng]] and a mixture of other unspecified ingredients, capable of curing [[HIV/AIDS]], [[Ebola virus disease]], other viral diseases, and "a number of cancers".[http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/kim-jong-un-claims-to-have-cured-aids-ebola-and-cancer-with-single-miracle-drug-10332386.html Kim Jong-un claims to have cured Aids, Ebola and cancer with single miracle drug] Independent.co.uk (June 8, 2016), retrieved September 12, 2016. Kumdang-2 website, retrieved September 12, 2016. ===Purges and executions=== As with all reporting on North Korea, individual reports of purges and executions are almost impossible to definitively verify.{{cite news|last1=Trianni|first1=Francesca|title=Did Kim Jong Un Really Execute His Uncle’s Extended Family?|url=http://time.com/2087/did-kim-jong-un-really-execute-his-uncles-extended-family/|accessdate=28 May 2016|work=TIME.com|date=27 January 2014|location=1:04-1:10 in embedded video}} Reports of numerous purges and executions are based in part on interviews with North Korean defectors, analysis of media issued by North Korea, non-independently-verifiable analysis of closed-source data from intelligence agencies, and occasionally satellite imagery. In December 2013, Kim Jong-un's uncle [[Jang Sung-taek]] was arrested and executed for treachery.[http://www.economist.com/news/asia/21591581-kim-jong-un-has-managed-improbable-feat-making-north-korea-even-scarier-crying-uncle Crying uncle] ''[[The Economist]]'', 14 December 2013.
